headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: I want to stay on the topic of the bundle, particularly in the U.S. market with 2 questions. John -- or actually Lachlan mentioned subscribers grew year-on-year, which is certainly encouraging. I think affiliate revenue growth decelerated from last quarte
componenttext: I want to stay on the topic of the bundle, particularly in the U.S. market with 2 questions. John -- or actually Lachlan mentioned subscribers grew year-on-year, which is certainly encouraging. I think affiliate revenue growth decelerated from last quarter year-on-year, so if there's any color or noise in those numbers that could help explain that, that would be helpful. And then for anyone who wants to take it, we're all focused on these new streaming packages coming out and at least I would argue that Sling and DirecTV Now have had some technology challenges in terms of the scaling. And I'm curious, how focused Twenty-First Century Fox is on that topic as it relates to Hulu, in particular, where you're an owner. And how confident are you that product is going to come out of the gate and be robust from a product offering scalability perspective? And should your shareholders be expecting that when that comes out over the next couple of months?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben. I'll deal with the first part of the question and James can take the second part. The affiliation revenue growth did decline very slightly in this quarter -- still an absolute positive and we would expect, as we've been saying for a while, th
componenttext: Thanks, Ben. I'll deal with the first part of the question and James can take the second part. The affiliation revenue growth did decline very slightly in this quarter -- still an absolute positive and we would expect, as we've been saying for a while, the new affiliation agreements start to take effect, we'll see that growth accelerate again towards the second half of the year.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, Ben, we were only a few million dollars away from rounding this to 8% from the 7%, so there's not a lot of noise inside of it.
componenttext: And I would just add, Ben, we were only a few million dollars away from rounding this to 8% from the 7%, so there's not a lot of noise inside of it.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Ben, thanks for your question. Look, I think the short answer is that the team at Hulu and certainly, what we're doing as well with our streaming apps, everyone is very, very focused on how do you solve some of the challenges in streaming, particularl
componenttext: And Ben, thanks for your question. Look, I think the short answer is that the team at Hulu and certainly, what we're doing as well with our streaming apps, everyone is very, very focused on how do you solve some of the challenges in streaming, particularly when you have a lot of concurrent streams. So I think we've seen really, really good progress in terms of our ability to stream concurrent streams of live sports of the high-volume entertainment programming, for example, of the Hotstar platform that I mentioned to you earlier as well as what our affiliate, Sky, kind of routinely does with Sky Go and NOW TV. And Hulu's working very hard on making sure that, that experience for customers is as good as it's possibly can be. You never rule out teething problems. And I think it's instructive or it's worthwhile kind of just mentioning that some of these problems in streaming, particularly concurrent live events, when everyone's logging in at the same second, is -- it's nontrivial. That said, we have a high degree of confidence in the Hulu platform, in the team there, their ability to deliver really a ton of minutes of streaming across their subscriber base currently. So we think it's going to be pretty strong. I think some of the things you've seen over the last number of months are normal for new services. And certainly, we expect those kind of kinks to be worked out. But certainly, it's not a -- it's not an easy technical challenge, but it's one that is surmountable and the team at Hulu is very, very focused on it. And I think the experience is going to be pretty good.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: And we go to Michael Morris with Guggenheim Securities.
componenttext: And we go to Michael Morris with Guggenheim Securities.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: Couple questions. First on Hulu. Can you talk about your expectation that the NBC Universal channels will be included in the streaming MVPD service? And it seems to reflect maybe in the near term a lack of support from one of the major Hulu partners for t
componenttext: Couple questions. First on Hulu. Can you talk about your expectation that the NBC Universal channels will be included in the streaming MVPD service? And it seems to reflect maybe in the near term a lack of support from one of the major Hulu partners for the product. Do you think that's the case? And does that impact sort of what can be done with that product? And then second, just on the Sky brand, it's a powerful brand in Europe, clearly. Do you see any opportunity that, brand could actually be brought to the U.S. and used in any way on any of your products?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Look, on Hulu, the matter -- the matter of Hulu's negotiation with third-party providers and content owners, it's really a matter for Hulu and one that they engage in, and we don't. That said, I know that the team there is very focused on pu
componenttext: Thanks, Mike. Look, on Hulu, the matter -- the matter of Hulu's negotiation with third-party providers and content owners, it's really a matter for Hulu and one that they engage in, and we don't. That said, I know that the team there is very focused on putting together a package of programs and brands that are going to really work for their customers and they'll make those decisions as the commercial negotiation kind of plays itself out. But I think the product is going to be pretty good. And look, I think you've never sort of -- you don't want to really engage in a lot of speculation about the future of the Sky business, et cetera. I think when you look at this business across the board, our focus on this brand and the FOX brands broadly on National Geographic, on the STAR brand and on the Sky brands in their regions of different levels of strength, has been one that we intend to continue. And if there's opportunities to grow those brands, as we did with the STAR brand, launching services to the South Asian Diaspora across Europe and in particular, the U.K. a number of years ago with great success, these things can live in different territories. But there are no plans at this point. Right now, we're focused on the strength of all of these brands and growing those -- growing all these businesses as best as we can within their kind of immediate neighborhoods to be honest.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: And we go to Anthony DiClemente with Nomura Instinet.
componenttext: And we go to Anthony DiClemente with Nomura Instinet.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: First question for James, this is about capital allocation. So pro forma Sky, the balance sheet will be a touch above 4x levered. Does this, do you think, will hold you back in any way either in terms of the buyback or in terms of strategic M&A? And more
componenttext: First question for James, this is about capital allocation. So pro forma Sky, the balance sheet will be a touch above 4x levered. Does this, do you think, will hold you back in any way either in terms of the buyback or in terms of strategic M&A? And more specifically, with the new administration and FCC regime, if the FCC regulations were relaxed to allow you to own more TV stations, question would be, would you have the inclination to look at acquiring TV stations that could come available? And the second question is for John and it's about Cable Network profitability. So last summer, your announced an incremental $200 million in investment in programming in Nat Geo and FX; you've now lapped the consolidation of Nat Geo Partners. The question is when might you expect Cable Network segment margins to return to expansion? Or said another way, when you look at the programming investments in Nat Geo and FX, when do those start to taper off such that the programming expense growth moderates?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony. Look, I think with respect to capital allocation, looking at the balance sheet going forward, I think the key thing to remember about the Sky transaction that we've kind of detailed in December was the rapid deleveraging profile of the co
componenttext: Thanks, Anthony. Look, I think with respect to capital allocation, looking at the balance sheet going forward, I think the key thing to remember about the Sky transaction that we've kind of detailed in December was the rapid deleveraging profile of the combined business. So yes, we sort of land at around 4x, a little bit above. It really delevers rapidly, and we're going to be focused on deleveraging, right. So we're going to put that at the top of the agenda for the numbers of just kind of quarters and years postclosing. So I think it kind of delevers pretty quickly, and I think we have capacity to do other things, either to think about additional capital returns by way of buybacks and continuing, obviously, with a growing dividend. Or potential kind of medium-sized or bolt-on M&A where we think capabilities and kind of expanding our business can make sense. But at this point, we're really focused on the shape of the business, as we've outlined to you. And as you can -- as you've seen and as we've shown you, I think that deleveraging profile there is pretty rapid and is pretty manageable for us. So no, we don't think it really curtails us, and this is the most sensible thing. As Lachlan made out in his early comments, we really think this is the best use of our capital at this point with the highest returns available to all shareholders, given the accretive nature of it and the pace of deleveraging. And with respect to potentially the FCC relaxing ownership caps on terrestrial TV stations in the U.S., no, I guess, is the most straightforward way to answer the question. I hate to comment on future sort of speculation and hypotheticals, but I can -- I think you can rest easy there. We really like the shape of our station business right now and while there always may be affiliation swaps or other little bits and pieces around the edges, no, we don't have a big appetite for adding much to that. And then I think it was 3 questions, John. Do you want to talk about programming or...?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yeah, I'll cover on the -- Anthony, on the expense trajectory, so this year was a step up for Nat Geo and FX, actually on a relative basis, more for Nat Geo with product like Mars and Genius and everything else, so they've begun the ramp-up of what we cal
componenttext: Yeah, I'll cover on the -- Anthony, on the expense trajectory, so this year was a step up for Nat Geo and FX, actually on a relative basis, more for Nat Geo with product like Mars and Genius and everything else, so they've begun the ramp-up of what we call a 2.0 strategy. We'll see a bit of it continuing into next year, but today was -- this year, I'm sorry, was the real ramp-up for Nat Geo. FX continues its trajectory toward its full schedule. We probably won't fully get there in the current year, but given the product and the success of what FX has done and particularly the success of its product, not only on FX but in other markets, that's an investment that the returns are just fabulous on.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017

componenttext: I think if you already look at Taboo, which premiered 3 or 4 weeks ago, which is part of -- the first part of that extra programming expense and it's been a terrific success. So doing that, and we'll be very happy.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: We'll go to Jessica Reif Cohen with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll go to Jessica Reif Cohen with Bank of America.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions. First, James, you talked a little bit about the next-generation apps. Can you talk a little bit about -- give us some color on how will you approach advertising within the apps? Second, as good as the numbers were this quarte
componenttext: I have a couple of questions. First, James, you talked a little bit about the next-generation apps. Can you talk a little bit about -- give us some color on how will you approach advertising within the apps? Second, as good as the numbers were this quarter, the outlook seems better. Comcast talked a little bit about their programming cost increases for the next 4 quarters. Can you give us any visibility on what the affiliate fee, domestic affiliate fee growth will look like? And how quickly -- on India, how quickly will you recover from the demonetization impact? And are there any other drivers that we should look for in the second half?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Jessica. In terms of advertising and the sort of asset, I think one thing that's really interesting is that, as we revamp -- and you'll see over the next kind of month and change, we'll start rolling out on a per-platform basis -- TVOS [ph]
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Jessica. In terms of advertising and the sort of asset, I think one thing that's really interesting is that, as we revamp -- and you'll see over the next kind of month and change, we'll start rolling out on a per-platform basis -- TVOS [ph] and then Android and then -- and so on as you kind of roll through the kind of the state out there. The authenticated apps really have a potential to reach an enormous audience. That 90 million or so MVPD households out there under our agreements had access to these apps, and what we need to do is really ease and simplify the authentication pathways. We need to create single logins across multiple brands, which will really make it easy and a great experience for customers. And we think we can generate some real audience there. Now that said, what's exciting about that is that that's a platform for us to innovate in terms of advertising, so that's around dynamic ad insertion. It's around pricing a customer's time in a different way. It's about engagement units and other things, really lowering the ad votes and getting a higher yield. We're already seeing nonlinear advertising growth at a very, very good clip in the U.S. and internationally. And that's because, from a data perspective and then a monetization perspective flowing from that, with innovative new ad products and different loads, you can have a much better experience. So we're going to approach it, first of all, by making sure the app platform is stable. It's not easy dealing with a number of systems, the number of MVPDs, all the different authentication kind of issues that are out there. But first of all, we want to make it stable, we want to make it a great experience. We're very focused on having a very, very big -- a large volume of content available on those apps. And we're going to kind of iterate in terms of how the advertising and monetization works. It's already going pretty well with the existing apps, and we think we're going to be able to enhance that experience and enhance our capabilities over the next number of months and through the rest of the year; it'll be a big focus for us.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: On the affiliate fee growth, just because I sort of answered the question a little bit before, Jessica, which was just -- with the renewal that we put on at the end of December and then with some new renewals that start rolling in March, we expect affilia
componenttext: On the affiliate fee growth, just because I sort of answered the question a little bit before, Jessica, which was just -- with the renewal that we put on at the end of December and then with some new renewals that start rolling in March, we expect affiliate fee growth to accelerate and really read the end of the year -- end of the fiscal year. So you can read in that the fourth quarter, when we see the acceleration kick in again.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, and it was obviously a little bit slower, we talked about earlier, just because of the anniversaries of deals, just didn't have any renewals at the right time; it's just the natural kind of cycle of it. And then with respect to the impact in India, l
componenttext: Yes, and it was obviously a little bit slower, we talked about earlier, just because of the anniversaries of deals, just didn't have any renewals at the right time; it's just the natural kind of cycle of it. And then with respect to the impact in India, look, I mean the demonetization, obviously, was a big impact in the quarter. We continue to feel some of that. It's ameliorated over the last month, and we expect that to kind of wash out of the system, but you will see that impact in this current quarter that we're in, and we have to really see what the fourth quarter looks like. I just want to reiterate that the business is performing pretty strongly. The impact is primarily associated with the entertainment advertising piece of this due to the nature of our clients and the nature of their business and how it's impacted by the demonetization. Viewing share is very strong, and we're very confident that the business, once it's through this kind of speed bump over a quarter or 2, will be able to get back on the trajectory towards the targets that we've outlined for '18, '19, '20 and beyond.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Michael Nathanson with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: And we'll go to Michael Nathanson with MoffettNathanson.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have 2 for James. James, question for you on Hulu is, since this idea first came up about a year ago, there's been a large list of new entrants to the space. You mentioned many of them, including Google. So as an owner of Hulu, where do you now see the
componenttext: I have 2 for James. James, question for you on Hulu is, since this idea first came up about a year ago, there's been a large list of new entrants to the space. You mentioned many of them, including Google. So as an owner of Hulu, where do you now see the opportunity to take share in what's becoming a pretty crowded marketplace?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, I think it's crowded in terms of the number of sort of names that are out there, but I don't think -- I think it's very, very nascent. I mean, we've seen Sling, obviously, first out the gate, but I guess Sony, Vue, Sling, DIRECTV, very
componenttext: Well, first of all, I think it's crowded in terms of the number of sort of names that are out there, but I don't think -- I think it's very, very nascent. I mean, we've seen Sling, obviously, first out the gate, but I guess Sony, Vue, Sling, DIRECTV, very recent. We expect the team at Hulu to be ready for a launch pretty soon. And we think there's a lot to play for. We think it's a big opportunity. I think for us, I guess, and we've been sort of talking about this for a little while, we think that, that proliferation of downstream competition is really, really healthy for content creators and for brands like ours that are robust, that are differentiated, that can really deliver content that works for customers. So we think that, that, a, from a 21CF perspective, that proliferation is going to be a positive thing for our business, and we do believe that it can reverse some of these overall declines in subscriber trends in the total MVPD universe and have that go forward. And then with Hulu, in particular, as you saw, I think Mike Hopkins did a great job kind of unveiling a lot of the details of the service at the plan service at CES earlier this year. I think that live viewing plus current plus past seasons and movies by really bundling the SVOD services with originals and library in past seasons in with what is the kind of current MVPD window, I think it's a very compelling offering that makes it simple for customers, that makes it exciting, and I think gives it a really unique, at this point, angle on the marketplace. So we think it could be very exciting. I think it's -- I would just say it is very early days. So even though we've seen a lot of announcements and we're seeing reasonable growth in these digital MVPDs, they are just starting from very little over 0 and it's a big market place and one that, I think, is going to benefit from a lot of this innovation.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think, James, just to add to that and it's important for people to remember, Hulu will be part of our great sort of ecosystem of these new DMVPDs, but one of the reasons Hulu's embarking on the strategy is also to influence that ecosystem and what the c
componenttext: I think, James, just to add to that and it's important for people to remember, Hulu will be part of our great sort of ecosystem of these new DMVPDs, but one of the reasons Hulu's embarking on the strategy is also to influence that ecosystem and what the core bundle looks like. So while we expect it to be very successful in its own right, it's already been successful in terms of having some influence in terms of how these packages or core channels are being put together.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to Richard Greenfield with BTIG.
componenttext: And we'll go to Richard Greenfield with BTIG.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. In the U.S., you've got your Hulu product that you've talked about and what's coming with the virtual MVPD for Hulu. But just wondering, even what you're talking about in terms of the technology that you're going to be fully consoli
componenttext: A couple of questions. In the U.S., you've got your Hulu product that you've talked about and what's coming with the virtual MVPD for Hulu. But just wondering, even what you're talking about in terms of the technology that you're going to be fully consolidating with Sky, and it seems like NOW TV, is there a path for FOX to build a, I guess for a lack of a better word, a direct FOX-to-consumer relationship rather than everything going through Hulu? And what could that look like? And then secondly, when you think about Hulu, it's an amazing product at $8. And I think, James, I know I've heard you speak at conferences about how when you launched the $12 product, it's actually driven home to people the value of the $8 product and really showing people the value of watching ads. How do you prevent the launch of a $40-ish product from showing people how much value there is to not watching live, and essentially, highlighting how great the $8 is versus the $40? How do you protect against that?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Rich. So look, I think the -- I think first of all, as I mentioned earlier, we're really focused on the streaming customer experience and a platform that we can deliver streaming content on to enable us to have the capabilities we talked ear
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Rich. So look, I think the -- I think first of all, as I mentioned earlier, we're really focused on the streaming customer experience and a platform that we can deliver streaming content on to enable us to have the capabilities we talked earlier about advertising. We talked about discovery of content, engagement generally. I gave you some numbers in my opening comments around how some of that has worked around the world in terms of those levels of engagement. But I think the goal for us is first to, as I said, really, create this product, a direct streaming product for customers, available to many, many, many millions of households on an authenticated basis who are already paying for the programming, and we can really enhance their experience with that programming, and we can also really enhance our capability in terms of monetizing that in addition to advertising lighter loads, et cetera. But certainly, it's also an option for us in the future whether or not we'd like to have an independently priced access to that suite of apps. And that's a decision that we haven't yet made but one certainly that we feel we have the capability and the general wherewithal and experience in terms of managing direct-to-consumer businesses and subscriber businesses to tackle. But right now, we're very focused with our MVPD partners and our new digital MVPD partners to making a customer experience that is as good as it can be. And those decisions around independently priced D2C platforms are something -- in the U.S. is something that can wait. 
I would note that between the Hotstar platform, both the free one and the premium tier there, and then the businesses at our affiliate, Sky, and the Tata Sky in India as well, many tens of millions of customers are on this vast direct-to-consumer platform today that is generating a lot of engagement and a lot of growth and a lot of profit. So we feel really good about that around the world as well. And whether or not there's a future for us in that, for example, the way that a TBS has taken some steps in those areas in the U.S., is a decision that we can take at a later date. 
And then with respect to pricing, look, I think pricing and packaging around these things is a challenging sort of art, if you will. It's a bit of science, but it's also a bit of art and the question is how do you make those -- how do you make the differentiation between those tiers really worthwhile for people, that they want to step up and do something that's a little bit more expensive, and you try to create steps for them, both up and down, so it doesn't just become in or out of a service, and certainly we did that, have done that for years at the Skys, and I think the team at Hulu are approaching it in a pretty smart way. A lot of it has to do with just how they -- how they're planning the product in the future. So I think you have to watch it carefully and you have to create packaging around that, that makes it understandable for customers exactly what they're getting. It's simple. It's straightforward. And then they can choose the prices that they like. And I would say that I think that the live programming, current and live sports, et cetera, are hugely valuable. And we see that in the uptake and penetration of the MVPD world today and in the engagement numbers and audiences that we're delivering, either through our sports businesses at the RSNs or at the broadcast network as we talked earlier and with a kind of recency and immediacy of new programming as it launches. So I think that does have value for people. But pricing, detailed pricing and packaging, going forward for Hulu is a matter for them that they're going to, I think, be articulating pretty, pretty soon and then also probably developing and changing it as it goes along.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: So we go to Steven Cahall with Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: So we go to Steven Cahall with Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just a couple from me. Maybe, first, just continue the affiliate fee discussion. I was under -- you've given a lot of detail. Can you remind us what percentage of the base of subs you've put on new deals in the last 18 to 24 months and what percentage you
componenttext: Just a couple from me. Maybe, first, just continue the affiliate fee discussion. I was under -- you've given a lot of detail. Can you remind us what percentage of the base of subs you've put on new deals in the last 18 to 24 months and what percentage you have coming up? And maybe if you could share the same for what you've got on retrans on the broadcast side of deals? And then also on cash, just wondering, you haven't talked a lot about working capital lately. What should our expectations be for working capital this year? And can you give us any indication of how much cash you might have on the balance sheet when you get to the end of the calendar year?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Feb 06, 2017

componenttext: Yes, sure on the -- I think -- I don't know that number, just on the top of my head, it's about 20% in terms of the sort of affiliate universe. And we actually don't have, going forward, a lot of lumpiness. We try to space that out so that every year or few quarters or so, we can have a step up here and there. We've got actually not a lot in the next few quarters, having done this recent deal, we've got a small one coming up and then it picks up again in '18.

componenttext: And Steve, from a cash perspective, we're a first-half, second-half company. So the first half usually is not our biggest cash flow period, so we'll have a very strong cash flow period in the second half of the fiscal year, including collecting all of the $500 million that Lachlan referred to earlier from the Super Bowl yesterday, while all the payments for that programming had been made in the first half of the year. So it's quite a healthy -- and will be a substantially growing position of cash before we get to the end of the year.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017

componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the 21st Century Fox Third Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
Now, I'd like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. Reed Nolte, Executive Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everybody, and welcome to our Third Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, Executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial
componenttext:
Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everybody, and welcome to our Third Quarter Fiscal 2017 Earnings Conference Call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, Executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial Officer.
First, we'll give some prepared remarks on the most recent quarter, and then we'll be happy to take questions from the investment community.
This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to 21st Century Fox's business strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. The company's Form 10-Q for the 3 months ended March 31, 2017, identifies risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ, and these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filing.
Additionally, this call will include certain non-GAAP financial measurements. The definition of and the reconciliation of such measures can be found in our earnings release and our 10-Q filing. Please note that certain financial measures used in this call, such as segment operating income before depreciation and amortization, often referred to as EBITDA, and adjusted earnings per share are expressed on a non-GAAP basis. The GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation of these non-GAAP measures is included in our earnings release.
And lastly, please note that our offer for Sky plc that was announced last December is governed by the U.K. takeover code. As such, there are strict limitations as to what we can say with respect to that transaction. We are restricted to providing information that has been publicly announced.
And with that, I'm pleased to turn it over to Lachlan.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Reed, and good afternoon, everyone. I apologize for a cold that I have. We are pleased to have delivered another quarter of solid growth. The strength of these results generated the highest core earnings per share in the company's history. This re
componenttext:
Thanks, Reed, and good afternoon, everyone. I apologize for a cold that I have. We are pleased to have delivered another quarter of solid growth. The strength of these results generated the highest core earnings per share in the company's history. This record result reflects continued positive progress across our businesses, with revenue and EBITDA growth coming from both our cable networks and Television segments.
And whilst earnings at the Film studio decreased, when compared to one of our most profitable film quarters ever in the prior year, when we benefited significantly from Deadpool, they were robust, nonetheless.
Importantly, we have driven our business forward against all our strategic priorities, through growing the distribution of our video brands on both traditional and demand emerging platforms, through innovating digital advertising products and partnerships, such as open AP and most critically, to delivering outstanding spelling, sports and news broadcasting.
In fact, the scale and health of our sports and news broadcasting businesses continued to be differentiators for us, with over half the company's advertising revenues earned in these genres.
Of course, we had an incredible Super Bowl, but we also saw viewership gains for the Daytona 500 on SBC and for MLS soccer on FOX Sports 1, which, for the first time, with ESPN2 for an entire month in February.
Additionally, viewership at our regional sports networks continues to be exceptionally strong, with Major League Baseball leading the way. Yankee ratings are up 39% over last season, and the Atlanta Brave's ratings are up over 54% this season so far. The business is in great shape, with all expiring team rights deals satisfactorily renewed.
Not to be outdone, Fox News is the #1 basic cable channel in both total day and primetime viewing for 61 consecutive quarters. In fact, Fox News has delivered its highest rated quarter ever, ratings strength we expect to continue.
In scripted programming, our partnerships with the world's best storytellers continued to produce groundbreaking new series that drive the long-term value of our core brands. FX debuted successful first seasons of Taboo, Legion and FEUD, adding to the network's reputation as a creative powerhouse.
National Geographic has made great progress its goal to more closely align its programming with its brand. The recent Genius premier, from producers Ron Howard and Brian bracer, Nat Geo's first scripted anthology series, drew over 4 million viewers in the U.S. alone, and was distributed further across the global reach of the National Geographic international channels.
The FOX broadcasting network's mixed performance in ratings this season has been frustrating for all, but we are encouraged by our development for the fall and look forward to presenting a strong schedule at our upfront this Monday.
Of course, the network does provide our TV studio a powerful launch platform for its shows, and it is important to consider these 2 businesses together. 20th Century Fox Television is coming off a stellar 2016/2017 broadcast season. This past year, our TV studio produced the #1 show on 5 different networks, including Empire on FOX, American Crime Story on FX, Modern Family on ABC, This Is Us on NBC and American Dad on TBS.
The solid performance of our film studio, with the box office successes of Logan and Hidden Figures, underscores the range and quality of what we bring our audiences. Looking out over the next year, we feel good about our slate, with Alien Covenant, directed by Ridley Scott, coming later this month; followed by War for the Planet of the Apes in July; Kingsman, the Golden Circle in September; and the Greatest Showman at Christmas. We've also recently announced the June 2018 release of Deadpool 2, dumping my young boys are widely looking forward to, but which they won't be allowed to watch.
Turning to our international businesses. The financial impact of the Indian demonetization we believe is behind us, but the financial impact has skewered impressive operational progress, most notably Star India's increasing its viewership lead over our competitors and the continued rise and drive of Hotstar as the emergent platform of choice in India. James will have some more to say about that in a few minutes.
The company continues to attract great new leaders, such as a Amy Listerman, who has joined us as Fox News CFO; and Marianne Gabelli, who has joined us as President of Fox News' advertising sales, and we welcome them to the company.
We feel good about where we are and confident that the strategic plan we continue to execute against is differentiating us from our competitors and building long-term value across our businesses.
With that, I'll hand it over to John.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lachlan, and good afternoon, everyone. Today, we reported another strong quarter of financial results, posting double-digit gains and adjusted earnings per share and growth in EBITDA, despite the very difficult year-on-year at our Film segment, wh
componenttext:
Thanks, Lachlan, and good afternoon, everyone. Today, we reported another strong quarter of financial results, posting double-digit gains and adjusted earnings per share and growth in EBITDA, despite the very difficult year-on-year at our Film segment, which Lachlan referred to.
Third quarter revenues increased $336 million, or 5%, to $7.56 billion, led by higher advertising revenues at the Television segment from the broadcast of this year's Super Bowl and affiliate revenue growth at the Cable Network segment. This was partially offset by slightly lower content revenues at the Film segment.
Total segment EBITDA for the third quarter was $1.94 billion, a 3% increase from the prior year, reflecting double-digit increases at our Television segment and mid-single-digit growth at the Cable Networks, offset in part by lower Film segment results from the challenging comp to a year ago.
From a bottom line perspective, we reported income from continuing operations attributable to stockholders of $811 million, or $0.44 per share. This quarter included charges of $142 million reported in other net, which primarily represents the fair value adjustments on currency hedges related to the pending Sky transaction.
Excluding the net income effect in both years of other net, impairment and restructuring and equity earnings adjustments, third quarter adjusted EPS was $0.54, which is a 15% increase over the comparable $0.47 reported a year ago.
So now turning to the performance of our operating segments for the third quarter. The cable network segment reported EBITDA of $1.45 billion, up 5% on revenue growth of 2%, with total segment expenses pretty much unchanged from last year. Domestic cable revenues increased 6%, led by affiliate fee growth of 8%, which reflects higher average rates across all of our brands.
Domestic ad revenues were equal to the prior year, as increases from the ratings strength at Fox News and at FS1 were offset by reductions from the nonchannel businesses at Nat Geo Partners. EBITDA at our domestic channel was equal to the prior year, as higher revenues were offset by increased investments in programming, most notably the planned investments to support our expansion of original series at FX and the new programming initiative at Nat Geo as well as contractual sports rights step-ups.
Third quarter reported international cable revenues declined 7%, as lower advertising and syndication revenues were partially offset by mid-single-digit affiliate fee growth. Reported advertising revenues were, as expected, down 18% versus the prior year, principally due to the absence of STAR's prior year broadcast of the ICC T20 World Cup and Asia Cup cricket tournaments and the continued negative impact from India's demonetization initiative.
Now, while the major effects of demonetization are now behind us, it negatively impacted the third quarter revenue by approximately $20 million. Reported international EBITDA contribution increased 44%, primarily due to the lower sports programming cost at STAR and affiliate fee growth.
At our Television segment, EBITDA in the quarter of $190 million increased 52% from last year on revenue increases of 30%. This revenue growth was driven by our broadcast of this year's Super Bowl, where we generated approximately $500 million in gross revenues on Super Bowl Sunday and from continued retransmission consent revenue growth. These increases more than offset the impact of lower primetime entertainment ratings from the absence of American Idol.
At the Film segment, third quarter EBITDA of $373 million was $97 million below a year ago. This quarter's very solid earnings were led by the theatrical releases of Logan and Hidden Figures, and higher television production contributions from the licensing of American Crime Story and Homeland.
The comparisons for last year's third quarter, as Lachlan mentioned, are challenging, since last year included significant contributions from the theatrical release of Deadpool and the home entertainment release of The Martian. These difficult comparisons will continue in the fourth quarter from the ongoing strength of these films last year as well as from the quarter -- quarterly timing of SVOD sales and reduced syndication sales versus last year's fourth quarter.
And finally, from a balance sheet perspective, we continue to accumulate cash reflecting our priority to point our capital towards a planned acquisition of Sky.
And with that, let me turn it over to James.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, John. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. So as you've heard, the first 9 months of the fiscal year have been strong, and we've made good progress on a number of fronts. But I just like to spend a minute or 2 ad
componenttext:
Thanks very much, John. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. So as you've heard, the first 9 months of the fiscal year have been strong, and we've made good progress on a number of fronts. But I just like to spend a minute or 2 addressing some of the key things we've been seeing in the marketplace and share some thoughts on our priorities going forward.
So a few points to make on the following subjects: the advertising trends and performance, the distribution universe for our video brands and the velocity of the business in terms of revenue that might not be so obvious at first glance.
So, first of all, we're very pleased with the advertising performance in the quarter, which grew 16% company-wide year-over-year. Now, obviously, as mentioned, at Super Bowl, was a major contributor, which was offset in part by the lack of both the Asian Cup and ICC T20 Championships at STAR, which we had in the comparable quarter last year and softer demand due to the effect of the demonization, as John mentioned, and the absence of America Idol at FBC, which had its final run on FOX last year. 
But it's important to note that all but one of our U.S. cable brands saw good advertising growth, with only the National Geographic Channel down, which we expected due to our shift in programming strategy that Lachlan talked about earlier. National Scatcher remains strong, although local appears a little softer than we'd like, particularly autos. But in months into the fourth quarter, we're looking for at least high digit growth for both our domestic and international cable portfolios.
As for the distribution landscape, a few highlights. Domestically, as John mentioned, we saw affiliate income growth year-on-year of about 8%, an acceleration from the same period last year and from the last quarter, as planned. We expect that growth to continue to accelerate in Q4 and into next year. 
The U.S. paid subscriber base for us was up slightly, about 0.5%, but, obviously, we saw some declines in the most widely distributed tiers of about 1.5% year-over-year, which we have not seen accelerating since last quarter.
In fact, everywhere we look, we see a landscape of opportunity, as downstream distribution becomes more innovative and competitive. Despite renewed market commentary over the last weeks, we remained of the view that innovation and competition from new entrants and incumbent operators, will ameliorate and then reverse the trends as digital rebundling drives overall universe growth.
At STAR, we continued to grow at a good pace, but the timing of some affiliate renewals last year affects this quarter's comparisons. You may recall that we had extraordinary growth last year in Q3 of some 20% in international cable affiliate revenue, so we're comping very nicely against a very high bar.
This year, we grew affiliate revenue in every key region, with some of the pace at FOX Network Group's international channels slowing due to some local events, such as the closure of 2 distributors in Thailand and some other weakness in Southeast Asia.
In the Hotstar platform in India continues to make strides, expanding its watch time over the prior quarter -- over the prior year quarter by 220%, making it, by some estimates, about 14x the watch time for Netflix.
In Europe, Asia and Latin America, we've introduced innovative nonlinear packages to each of their regions, under the labels Fox Plus and FOX premium, all tailored for a specific market and offering consumers more choice, a better experience and ultimately, for us, making a better business.
In the U.S., the digital MVPD revolution has only now reached the starting line. So taken altogether, if we exclude the Film segment, which, obviously, didn't have a Deadpool in the quarter, revenue globally grew at about 11%. We think that's a pretty good clip, and it's a testament to the diversity and the breadth of the business geographically and by mix. And year-to-date, our EBITDA is up 11%, which underscores how all these comes together, with a durable velocity underlying the business.
I want to reiterate that our strategy of focus on big brands that matter for customers and investment on screen that clearly differentiates and earns attention and a program of work to make our programming and products more available, not less, is paying dividends.
Our business has been an expression of a technological advance shaping our industry from way back, from silent movies to talkies, from featured film exhibitions to broadcast Television and from broadcast to multichannel cable and satellite TV. And the underlying technological advances today, ubiquitous high-speed connectivity, a continued proliferation of end-user connected displays and the potential for unfettered access to creative assets in the cloud for customers globally, presents an opportunity for accelerated growth for new and existing video creators and platforms. We think this is only just the beginning, and a combination of strengths required to operate a high-volume content business and a vast international video platform is precisely the combination of strengths that we're developing.
In short, if content is indeed king and using it to build platforms that are an expression of these current underlying trends, presents the most promising opportunity for our company in decades.
Now, before closing, I'd like to quickly touch upon Sky. The business continues to deliver on its growth strategy, recently reporting good financial performance, with subscriber growth across the group. Last month, we welcomed the decision by the European Commission clearing unconditionally our proposed transaction. And we continue to work with U.K. regulators, and we're confident that the proposed transaction will be completed by the end of this calendar year, as we've said before.
Thanks very much, and we're happy to take any questions you may have. Reed?

componenttextpreview: Given that you're the last major media company to report, and we appreciate the update of your subscriber trends, no one yet is ever a -- has framed how big the virtual IBP universe is currently, so can you tell us, [indiscernible] how much -- how big vir
componenttext: Given that you're the last major media company to report, and we appreciate the update of your subscriber trends, no one yet is ever a -- has framed how big the virtual IBP universe is currently, so can you tell us, [indiscernible] how much -- how big virtual subs have been for you in the past quarter? And what was that -- what was the number a quarter ago, so just give us a sense of within your trends, how much is a virtual MVPD business helping stabilize your course trends?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael. So first of all, I don't want to get into disclosing 2 individual -- individual partners of ours kind of pay customer numbers, but I would say that it is very, very early days. And really, I think mostly for us, the thing I'd like to poin
componenttext: Thanks, Michael. So first of all, I don't want to get into disclosing 2 individual -- individual partners of ours kind of pay customer numbers, but I would say that it is very, very early days. And really, I think mostly for us, the thing I'd like to point out, is number one, the inclusion of our core brands and the investment in those core brands that we've been making over the last couple of years has really worked in terms of inclusion in new virtual MVPDs in every major one, all pretty much all of our brands are there, and we see that growing pretty fast over the next number of quarters and years. But to date, it's a pretty small number because you really have really just DIRECTV NOW and Sling in the quarter, and a little bit of Sony, but it's really now, I think, the increased competition, YouTube launching after this quarter, I think it was just in April, and Hulu really just getting out of the gates last week. So it's really just early days there. So what's really driving us more is the fact that we've been investing in these brands. And some of our brands are less mature, and we have continued growth in a number of our channels in terms of the existing traditional MVPD subscriber base as well. And think, and I think there's actually one of our major brands saw any shrinkage in the quarter.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Michael, I'd add to what James said, and James also touched upon in his prepared remarks. There really pleasing thing from our point of view is how different all the emerging key MVPDs are, and they're targeting different segments of the consumer audience
componenttext: Michael, I'd add to what James said, and James also touched upon in his prepared remarks. There really pleasing thing from our point of view is how different all the emerging key MVPDs are, and they're targeting different segments of the consumer audience. So between DIRECTV NOW and Sling TV, YouTube, obviously, Hulu and PlayStation view, they're all very different services. And we think this is incredibly important because not only are they designed, and many of them are designed to replace traditional MVPDs subscriber numbers and losses, but they're targeting entirely new segments of the -- of U.S. households. Segments that don't -- that have brought Mendon but potentially don't have traditional MVPD, so that's why gives us a lot of confidence, as James mentioned in his remarks, that not only will these new services ameliorate decline in traditional MVPDs but will actually grow the universe quite significantly over time.

componenttext: We'll see -- I'm only looking forward to the fourth quarter, John, but as I do, we'll see kind of mid-single on the domestic side, which is the continued investment in Nat Geo and FX for the programming, but we don't have a big sports welcome having domestically. But uniquely, international, we have a big cricket event and STAR, the champions trophy, so we'll see a touch -- we'll see a higher growth in that quarter uniquely for that event. Otherwise, our expenses should be in that mid-single zone.

componenttextpreview: I was hoping for some more detail on India, James. I mean competitor highlighted yesterday that the Indian marketplace is challenging, and they were pleased to add low exposure that, obviously, conflicts with your commentary in the prepared remarks. Can y
componenttext: I was hoping for some more detail on India, James. I mean competitor highlighted yesterday that the Indian marketplace is challenging, and they were pleased to add low exposure that, obviously, conflicts with your commentary in the prepared remarks. Can you talk about the trajectory towards the long-term target of $1 billion of profitability? And at what point Hotstar is cannibalistic? And any thoughts in the marketplace relative to that other point of view would be helpful.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: So thanks, Doug. Look, we're very enthusiastic about our business in India. I think what we're seeing there today is -- Lachlan mentioned, increased level of leadership in terms of our entertainment share. Our sports business is really going from strength
componenttext: So thanks, Doug. Look, we're very enthusiastic about our business in India. I think what we're seeing there today is -- Lachlan mentioned, increased level of leadership in terms of our entertainment share. Our sports business is really going from strength to strength, since we kind of -- since we acquired the half of the ESPN Star Sports joint venture a number of years ago, and really reinvented STAR Sports in the marketplace, it's been very, very successful. Not just in cricket, but also with the [indiscernible] and with the Indian Super League, the soccer league there, where they're rounding out the schedule, so feel good about it. When I look at the marketplace, we have is we had a disruption with the demonetization, as John mentioned. That's largely -- we're largely through that now it wasn't big an impact in the last quarter, and we're at the run rate that we need to be at to get to our target at this point. So we feel on target, we feel like the business is in pretty robust health. Creatively, is performing very, very well, and we feel confident about the overall Indian environment generally. I did note some of those comments. I heard about that, and I was surprised because at least from our business perspective, we take the view that you go into a market like India in the expectation that in success, it's really going to change your life. So you really don't go anything other than the whole hog, and that has really paid off well. We have a very profitable and exciting business there, and I think it speaks to really the differentiation you're seeing across the media sector today. When I look at all the very performance that I think I urge you to think about all of these firms of different strengths and weaknesses. And our business has been on a very clear path to that, investing in these big brands around the world, being global first, getting exposure to markets that we think in success can really, really move the dial for us and investing on screen for customers in a way that is committed to the best possible content experience they can have. And maybe that's different from other players.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have to 2, 1 for James and 1 for John. James, just wanted to ask about the appointment of Jomar Casey as the Head of Ad Sales. We talked about the new model and kind of given his background in advance advertising, what is that appointment say? What is y
componenttext: I have to 2, 1 for James and 1 for John. James, just wanted to ask about the appointment of Jomar Casey as the Head of Ad Sales. We talked about the new model and kind of given his background in advance advertising, what is that appointment say? What is your thought process in appointing, Joe, say about your expectations or where the TV broadcast advertising model is going in terms of ad product? And then for John, you guys have really outperformed the market in terms of domestic affiliate revenue growth. Of course, that's due to some recent large distributor renewals at least 1, so can you just talk a little bit more about the outlook for that? I mean I think James said in his prepared remarks, strong growth heading into '18. I think some folks are wondering about the second half of '18, after you kind of lap that big renewal and a step up from that, so no other renewal of health, and can you just remind us what portion of your footprint is up by that time that can perhaps pick up -- pick you guys up despite the anniversary? I hope that makes sense.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, May 10, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anthony. The -- well, I think on the advertising side, obviously, when you have leadership changes and transitions, you really look to what you think the needs of the business are going to be over time, and in the future. And I think in Joe and al
componenttext: Thanks, Anthony. The -- well, I think on the advertising side, obviously, when you have leadership changes and transitions, you really look to what you think the needs of the business are going to be over time, and in the future. And I think in Joe and also Danielle, [indiscernible], who's also reporting to Randy [indiscernible] in that area. We've got leaders that are really very, very capable. We think that -- and I think the advance advertising piece combining with that sort of core advertising sort of broader TV advertising piece, I think is -- just makes a lot of logical sense. We look at this business as an audience business and an attention business. And having an organizational structure and the leaders of it aligned with that is the right strategy going forward, and we're really excited to -- about the next chapter for our domestic ad business. Lachlan, do you want to add anything to that?

componenttext: I think it's interesting, if you go on YouTube TV, for example, and you see the #1 trending live channel and shows on emerging DMVPD, it's almost always the case Fox News, and that continues, obviously, post a lot of the programming changes and lineup that we've had. As I've said, the channel continues its ratings dominance moving forward very strongly, very strong with both affiliates and with our advertising sales, so -- and we're very confident in the future of that business.

componenttextpreview: It's -- the, first of all, look, what I don't think is that this -- I think this is not the quorum to get into kind of hypothetical conversations around M&A that may or may not have happened. I would save that, in the end, we didn't bid for Tribune, and w
componenttext: It's -- the, first of all, look, what I don't think is that this -- I think this is not the quorum to get into kind of hypothetical conversations around M&A that may or may not have happened. I would save that, in the end, we didn't bid for Tribune, and we've talked about this with the investment community and our shareholders in the past year. The station business is a strong business for us, it's an important part of our network distribution. It's a strong business in terms of local programming, local news, and so on. But it isn't a place that we're targeting to deploy capital into, and so anything that we look out there is more about can we change our strategic position? Can we think about scale in a different way, but not in a way that would be a -- not in a way that would be a use of capital for us at all, just to be clear. But it remains -- look, it's a strong business, and I think the local -- relevance of those local brands in the local stations and their communities continues to be very high.
