componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the 21st Century Fox First Quarter 2018 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I'd now like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. Reed Nolte, Executive Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our first quarter fiscal 2018 earnings conference call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, Executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial
componenttext:
Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our first quarter fiscal 2018 earnings conference call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, Executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial Officer. 
First, we will give some prepared remarks on the most recent quarter, and we'll be happy to take questions from the investment community. This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to 21st Century Fox' business strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. 
The company's Form 10-Q for the 3 months ended September 30, 2017, identifies risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ, and these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filings. 
Additionally, this call will include certain non-GAAP financial measurements. The definition of and a reconciliation of such measures can be found in our earnings release and our 10-Q filing. 
Please note that certain financial measures used in this call, such as segment operating income before depreciation and amortization, often referred to as EBITDA, and adjusted earnings per share are expressed on a non-GAAP basis. The GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures is included in our earnings release. 
And lastly, please note that our offer for Sky plc that was announced last December is covered by the U.K. takeover code. As such, there are strict limitations as to what we can say with respect to that transaction, and we are restricted to providing information that has been publicly announced. 
And with that, I'm pleased to turn the call over to Lachlan.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Reed, and good afternoon, everyone. Let me be very clear upfront that we have a long-standing policy of not commentating -- commenting on speculation around corporate activity or transactions. We will continue to adhere to that policy, meaning t
componenttext:
Thanks, Reed, and good afternoon, everyone. Let me be very clear upfront that we have a long-standing policy of not commentating -- commenting on speculation around corporate activity or transactions. 
We will continue to adhere to that policy, meaning that we will not be responding at all to questions or comments regarding recent press speculation. 
The purpose of this call is to focus on the growing and robust business of 21st Century Fox. We are pleased to report a solid start to fiscal 2018, which continues the operational and financial progress we delivered in fiscal '17. 
In the last quarter, we delivered 8% top line growth, with increases across all our reporting segments and revenue categories. We drove an acceleration in domestic affiliate revenue, which grew by 11%, sequentially surpassing the strong 10% growth in the prior quarter. 
We maintained our aggregate domestic subscriber levels, offsetting declines in the traditional pay TV universe, with growing contribution from our younger channel and our new digital MVPD partners. 
The latter now approaches 3 million subscribers despite only limited marketing for their products so far. 
We talk often about our unique competitive advantage of our strength in local and national sports and news in an environment with increased viewing optionality, and this trend continues. 
We essentially doubled college football viewership from higher ratings and more games. We grew our Major League Baseball regular season ratings at our RSNs by 5%, with 7 teams up double digits, and more recently finished October as the most watched month in FOX Sports 1 history on the back of postseason baseball. 
And speaking of baseball, it was another great 7-game World Series for us, both onscreen and financially. 
Fox News maintains its position as the #1 network on basic cable and had its 63rd consecutive quarter as the highest-rated cable news channel in total viewers. 
And while the local stations face a difficult comparison with the heavy political advertising last year, the underlying market is up, led by a healthy auto category and improving retail advertising. 
In entertainment, our Film and Television divisions continue to create new hits to refresh longer-term content revenue streams.
At FBC, The Gifted, The Orville and Ghosted have all performed well as freshmen series. At FX, 3 returning shows, The Strain, Better Things and American Horror Story, all increased their viewership over the prior year quarter. 
And National Geographic continues its focus on brand-supportive content, including the upcoming Long Road Home series. 
And at our film studio, we have a strong upcoming slate that includes Murder on the Orient Express this weekend, The Greatest Showman, The Post by Steven Spielberg, X-Men: New Mutants and Deadpool 2. 
Overall, our performance underscores the success of our core strategies, including owning and investing in distinctive must-have brands and IP, distributed to global consumers every minute of every day. 
The power of these strong and unique brands supports our content, our advertising and critically, our leading growth in affiliate fee revenues; continually expanding our deep and unique access to international markets through an unparalleled global footprint, with particular emphasis in one of the largest growth economies in the world, India; and challenging the status quo by consistently driving innovation across our businesses by leaning into new distribution models, new ad tech monetization capabilities and being a global leader in direct-to-consumer offerings. 
For example, we told you many years ago that innovative disruption would come to our industry. We embraced it and continued to see more and more exciting changes and resulting opportunities. 
We moved early to jettison our thin brands and went deep with investments into our rich, distinctive brands when many market pundits were skeptical of this approach. Because of these investments, our brands have been rewarded with full distribution on all traditional and newly launched platforms. 
Now there is a lot of talk about the growing importance of scale in the media industry, and let me be very clear, FOX has the required scale to continue to both execute on our growth strategy and deliver increased returns to shareholders. 
We are specifically seeing this in our affiliate fee growth again this quarter, in the success of Hulu and in our inclusion in all of the emerging VMVPDs. 
We are excited about all of our brands and the breadth of opportunities they continue to offer the company. All in all, our progress in the quarter keeps us on pace with our fiscal 2018 objectives and directly in line with our long-term plan, however, long-term delivery coming from an intense day-to-day focus towards being the very best in storytelling, in journalism, in sports and in innovation to consumers worldwide. 
Driving these businesses is a stellar management team, from Peter Rice at the Fox Networks Groups, to Uday Shankar's STAR, Stacey Snider, John Landgraf, Eric Shanks, Carlos Martinez, Dana Walden, Gary Newman, Jack Abernethy, Brian Sullivan, along with our 22,000 colleagues around the world, we are singularly and intensely focused on delivering on our strategic plan. 
Our businesses and brands are stronger than ever and have the right management and strategies to achieve market-leading value accretion. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to John.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lachlan, and good afternoon, everyone. We reported our first quarter financial results today, highlighted by revenue growing 8% to reach $7 billion. It was led by double-digit growth at the Cable Network segment and increases at the Film and Telev
componenttext:
Thanks, Lachlan, and good afternoon, everyone. We reported our first quarter financial results today, highlighted by revenue growing 8% to reach $7 billion. It was led by double-digit growth at the Cable Network segment and increases at the Film and Television segments. 
Segment EBITDA for the quarter of $1.79 billion was in line with last year's result as company-wide revenue growth was offset by expected higher cost, largely due to the higher volume of sports events broadcasts in the current quarter at the Cable and Television segments. 
From a bottom line perspective, we reported income from continuing operations attributable to stockholders of $839 million or $0.45 per share, while adjusted EPS was $0.49. 
So with those highlights, I'll provide some added comments on the performance of our operating segments for the quarter and starting with the Cable Network segment, where EBITDA of $1.51 billion was up 9% on revenue growth of 10% and expense growth, primarily from sports volume, of 11%. But notably, this expense increase reflects a 2-percentage point impact from the inclusion of sublicense sports rights. 
Domestic cable revenues increased 9%, led by 11% affiliate fee growth and advertising revenue growth of 3%. The affiliate fee increase reflects higher average rates across all of our domestic brands. The advertising growth largely reflects higher viewership across our sports network. 
EBITDA at our domestic channels increased 11% over the prior year, reflecting these higher revenues, partially offset by increased costs from added college football and soccer games at FS1 and Major League Baseball rights increases at FS1 and the RSNs. 
Reported international cable revenues grew 13%, driven also by an 11% increase in reported affiliate revenue and a 10% increase in reported advertising revenue. 
International content and other revenues increased 35% over the prior year due to the sublicensing of Latin American soccer rights to third parties, which is offset in expenses. 
Reported international EBITDA contributions were consistent with the prior year, reflecting the higher revenues being offset by expected higher programming costs, largely from increased soccer in Latin America from the inaugural broadcast of the Argentine Football Association and from the timing of Conmebol matches. 
At our Television segment, EBITDA was $122 million, 36% below last year. Television segment revenues grew 3% on higher retransmission consent revenue and increased sports advertising revenue from a higher volume of college football games and one additional NFL game. These ad sale gains were partially offset by reduced political advertising at the stations. 
Our net revenue improvement was more than offset by higher sports rights from the increased volume of football games and normal rights increases. 
At the Film segment, first quarter EBITDA of $256 million was $55 million below a year ago. This decrease was primarily driven by lower contributions at the Film division, led by lower sales in international TV markets. 
Overall, Film segment revenues in the quarter were 3% higher than the prior year, primarily due to higher Television production revenues led by the domestic syndication sale of Futurama. 
And finally, from a balance sheet perspective, we ended the quarter with $6.9 billion in cash and $19.8 billion in debt. Our capital allocation priority continues to be focused on funding the Sky acquisition. 
So all in all, a good start to achieving our fiscal 2018 financial objectives. On our last earnings call, I mentioned a number of comparability items to be aware of as we progressed through this fiscal year, and at this time, I don't have any meaningful changes to those items. 
So one addition of note since the call is our successful acquisition of the IPL cricket rights in India starting this coming spring. These worldwide rights will add approximately 3 percentage points of cost growth to the Cable segment, and we expect a similar dollar amount of incremental revenues to be generated from these matches all in the fourth quarter. 
And with that, let me turn it over to James.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, John and Lachlan. Thanks, everyone, for joining the call today. So as you've heard, fiscal 2018 has started pretty well. 1 quarter in, we're on track to generate meaningful growth and to deliver operational advances that are going to s
componenttext:
Thanks very much, John and Lachlan. Thanks, everyone, for joining the call today. 
So as you've heard, fiscal 2018 has started pretty well. 1 quarter in, we're on track to generate meaningful growth and to deliver operational advances that are going to serve the company well going forward. 
We're committed to our strategy of producing both highly localized content around the world and broad global franchises that travel well and together, build resident brands in our marketplace -- in our key markets. 
New digital platforms, in partnership with us, are leading the way and improving the customer experience and allowing us to make high-quality storytelling, sports and news programming more available, not less, which will drive further consumption of our content and more visibility into that consumption by our customers, strengthening our business. 
And across the company, the whole company, we're making really good progress. For example, in Argentina, which will soon be our largest South American market, the launch of our premium sports business, anchored by our long-term rights agreement with the AFA, has exceeded all of our expectations. 
We've added more local stations in sports to FOX NOW. The international rollouts of Fox Plus and FOX Premium continue to gain traction. And Hotstar, which continues to set the pace for streaming in India, recently launched internationally for the Indian diaspora, providing opportunities to further monetize our Indian investments. 
Additionally, the rollout of FX+ on Comcast systems, which allows us to resurface, repackage and monetize great content from our library as well as current output in an ad-free premium environment, is showing great promise. 
It also recently launched on Cox systems, and others are expected to follow shortly. 
Our commitment to deliver a less cluttered viewing experience does not necessarily come at the expense of lower advertising yields. 6-second spots during the NFL, the launch of Open AP, addressable ads in on-demand and streaming on Hulu are all examples of innovation we have embraced in this space. In fact, Fox Networks Group digital ad revenue in aggregate is up 30% year-over-year, with revenue per stream on our apps up 50% at FBC, 130% at FX and up 300% at FOX Sports. 
Perhaps most encouragingly, as we predicted to you over a year ago at our broadcast network entertainment business, the combination of ad-free premiums and nonlinear advertising sales now outpaces the linear revenue decline driven by customers' preference for timeshifting their viewing. 
Before closing, I'd like to reiterate 2 meaningful milestones we expect to achieve before the end of this fiscal year. First, at STAR, our significant past investments and current investments in entertainment, sports, regional and our mobile platform, Hotstar, position the company as the premier Indian content and digital distribution company. 
First quarter results keep us on plan to achieve $500 million of EBITDA target this fiscal year as projected and with velocity heading into the next few years. 
And as John mentioned, STAR just recently took its final step in the realignment of its sports portfolio with the acquisition of those 5-year rights for the Indian Premier League, the most attended and watched cricket league in the world. Exclusive global rights across broadcasting and digital will be a key growth driver of this business going forward. 
These rights cement our confidence in achieving our financial targets for our Indian business, and our aspiration for the business over the long-term continues to grow. 
Secondly, we're engaging with the U.K. regulators on our proposed Sky acquisition. We're confident this transaction will accelerate the company's operational and financial growth, and we anticipate the transaction to close by the middle of 2018. 
In conclusion, the trajectory and the velocity of the business are good. The business is well positioned, we've made a lot of progress, and we're excited about the upcoming years. 
And as Lachlan pointed out, we can't comment on market speculation, but we're happy to discuss our business and the quarter's results. So over to you.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from the line of Ben Swinburne with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: I will stick with one topic, which is the virtual MVPD trends you're seeing in the U.S. I don't know, John, if you're willing to give us a little more granularity on what drove what seemed to be a pretty nice acceleration in affiliate revenues in the U.S.
componenttext:
I will stick with one topic, which is the virtual MVPD trends you're seeing in the U.S. I don't know, John, if you're willing to give us a little more granularity on what drove what seemed to be a pretty nice acceleration in affiliate revenues in the U.S. I don't believe you had any renewals at the end of June. So I'm wondering if maybe the volumes got better overall for you. So any color there would be helpful. 
And then I wanted to ask the team about Hulu, which is obviously a major player in that 3 million subscriber number you mentioned. You made a management change -- or there was a management change made there recently. Maybe if you can just talk about how you're feeling about Hulu's live product, the sort of product road map, and whether you still are excited about what that business can do from a bundle perspective going forward.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben. It's John to start. Volumes held up pretty well for us. The inclusion or the advent of these VMVPD products have just been a real success in capturing subs, either from traditional or Hulu or outside the system altogether. So the real growth
componenttext: Thanks, Ben. It's John to start. Volumes held up pretty well for us. The inclusion or the advent of these VMVPD products have just been a real success in capturing subs, either from traditional or Hulu or outside the system altogether. So the real growth that we achieved on the 11% was in rate step-ups across every one of our brands. And it goes back to the point that both James and Lachlan were making, we spent a long time investing in these brands, and now we're harvesting the value from them.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Ben, I think that's right. So you have this -- we have this rate increase from previous -- step-ups from previous affiliate agreements, not in the quarter, but volume holding up well. And look, it's a little bit mixed. I think you saw the telco k
componenttext:
Yes, and Ben, I think that's right. So you have this -- we have this rate increase from previous -- step-ups from previous affiliate agreements, not in the quarter, but volume holding up well. And look, it's a little bit mixed. I think you saw the telco kind of distributors shrink at a greater rate than some of the cable and DBS. But fundamentally, new competition is driving growth, right? And I think in the -- from a billable subs perspective, this is on a couple of months' lag in these numbers of about 2 million, but just in the last few months, they have added another million of VMVPDs, right? So it's almost 3 million, as Lachlan mentioned today. And that's only going to accelerate from here because really, that's prior to the marketing that we saw from YouTube, the upcoming kind of more aggressive marketing from Hulu, and we think others as well. DIRECTV NOW, Sling, fubo, with its sports focus and a slightly different kind of package, is growing well. So we feel really good about that. And I think it's important, just before I get to Hulu, to reemphasize that the streaming MVPD, the VMVPD, if you will, is a really great platform for us. And we think it's an incredible set of platforms for monetizing our programming and our investment, and it's a great user experience as well. And it's really in line with what we've been trying to accomplish and have been talking to all of you guys about over the last couple of years, and I think you can really start to see that coming through in this quarter. 
With respect to Hulu, yes, look, I wouldn't read too much into the management change. I mean, Mike Hopkins left to take a great job at Sony, is a longtime colleague of ours and was a great leader of Hulu. And I'm really excited for Randy Freer, who came out of the Fox Networks Group to go over to Hulu very recently, and we're sure that that's going to continue -- that's going to help continue the momentum and really good pace that the Hulu business has. So we feel good about Hulu Live. It's growing well. It's early days. We feel great about Hulu's product and product road map. And I think what we're going to see is Hulu and a number of other of these VMVPDs continue to be real pacesetters in the marketplace, both from a customer experience perspective, a content offering perspective and a volume perspective, offsetting a lot of the declines that we've seen over the last sort of while. And as I think I've said in the last quarterly call, we expected actually -- we think that the so-called pay TV universe, the universe of people paying for video services, in these multiservice providers is actually going to grow.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: And look, James -- yes, and look, I think -- sorry, Ben. Look, I think that's exactly right, and I'll just reinforce what James said about the -- we were extraordinarily pleased to see the YouTubeTV marketing as the major sponsor of our Major League Baseb
componenttext: And look, James -- yes, and look, I think -- sorry, Ben. Look, I think that's exactly right, and I'll just reinforce what James said about the -- we were extraordinarily pleased to see the YouTubeTV marketing as the major sponsor of our Major League Baseball World Series because this is really -- I think it marks the beginning of what you're going to see as a very significant growth curve for all of these services.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: A question comes from the line of Michael Nathanson with MoffettNathanson.
componenttext: A question comes from the line of Michael Nathanson with MoffettNathanson.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to ask about press speculation, but I'll ask about strategy. I think there's been a perception, right or wrong, that FOX and News Corp before has always been a collector of assets. And I wonder, can you share your view of whether or not the
componenttext: I'm not going to ask about press speculation, but I'll ask about strategy. I think there's been a perception, right or wrong, that FOX and News Corp before has always been a collector of assets. And I wonder, can you share your view of whether or not the industry's trends have changed enough that makes you rethink your asset mix for the long term? Aside from getting Sky, so I just want to know just thematically, if you got it at the right scale, does scale matter as much in entertainment as it maybe once did, or does it matter more?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael. It's James here. I'll just take a crack at it, and then Lachlan might want to jump in. But look, first of all, I don't think we're -- I -- yes, we're not a collector, we're an operator. And I think what we try to do is build a business th
componenttext: Thanks, Michael. It's James here. I'll just take a crack at it, and then Lachlan might want to jump in. But look, first of all, I don't think we're -- I -- yes, we're not a collector, we're an operator. And I think what we try to do is build a business that can have pace, that can have velocity, that can deliver value over the long term. And as you know, we've taken a lot of steps to change our portfolio over the last number of years, simplifying our mix of assets, investing in these core brands, selling assets that weren't going to change our lives in terms of a lot of the -- I can go all the way back to the Russian outdoor business, which we exited a number of years ago. So I think the point for us is we've really simplified our operating model. We've got a great set of brands and a great set of assets that we really like. And as you can see from these quarterly results and from the last couple of quarters, I hope, a real trajectory of good performance in those. It's never easy. We're focused on operating these businesses as best we can with a really incredible management team at all of these businesses, and we can continue to be focused on that. So we like that mix, we like these brands, and we're seeing them really perform around the world, from STAR to the FOX businesses around the world, National Geographic. These are big brands that really matter for their customers, and we like where we are.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Look, James, that's 100% correct. And look, I think, historically, the truth is we've always been asset-builders, and whether it's Sky or STAR or Fox News or the Fox Network, we operate these businesses to build them and to grow, and we will continue to d
componenttext: Look, James, that's 100% correct. And look, I think, historically, the truth is we've always been asset-builders, and whether it's Sky or STAR or Fox News or the Fox Network, we operate these businesses to build them and to grow, and we will continue to do so.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say to both of you guys, I think many people on The Street see the growth and the value you've created, and they're frustrated the stock has not reflected that growth and you trade at levels that are closer to some companies that don't grow.
componenttext: Well, I would say to both of you guys, I think many people on The Street see the growth and the value you've created, and they're frustrated the stock has not reflected that growth and you trade at levels that are closer to some companies that don't grow. So is there a frustration within the family or the executives that you're not getting credit for all of the things you've done over the many years?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Look, all we can do is work on what we can control, and that's operating these businesses and growing the businesses. And that's what every single member of senior management is focused on.
componenttext: Look, all we can do is work on what we can control, and that's operating these businesses and growing the businesses. And that's what every single member of senior management is focused on.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: It comes from the line of Jessica Reif with Bank of America.
componenttext: It comes from the line of Jessica Reif with Bank of America.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: I had a question on, I guess, 2 things, one, the -- on the ad tech platform. Can you -- you talked about kind of the stuff you're doing now. Can you talk about milestones for the year or 2 ahead? What will finally tip the scales for targeted advertising?
componenttext: I had a question on, I guess, 2 things, one, the -- on the ad tech platform. Can you -- you talked about kind of the stuff you're doing now. Can you talk about milestones for the year or 2 ahead? What will finally tip the scales for targeted advertising? And then, I guess, to think of the unthinkable, if you don't get the Sky approval, given all the kind of political stuff going on in the U.K., how do you think about the use of excess capital?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jessica. In terms of a -- It's James. It terms of the advertising capability, we continue to improve our ad capability across the piece. I think there are a few milestones to look at. I think the adoption of standards across the sort of streaming
componenttext:
Thanks, Jessica. In terms of a -- It's James. It terms of the advertising capability, we continue to improve our ad capability across the piece. I think there are a few milestones to look at. I think the adoption of standards across the sort of streaming video industry, I think the Open AP platform, which we're a big proponent of, I think is important. I think seeing third-party verification really take root across digital advertising, both on -- from social networks to streaming video platforms, I think is going to be really important. And then there's an industry thing that we're working very hard to sort of get in place. But fundamentally, we're not waiting on that to innovate, right? So I look at it and think, let's not wait to try to move this whole kind of armada of companies to something, let's actually go out there and iterate and find the ad products that are going to make sense for customers. And that's an ad product that, for example, you could buy out if you're a customer and not have ads and you value your time more than Coca-Cola does, or it's ad products that are great for customers in pitching changes, like the 6-second spots and picture-in-picture stuff. So it's not just digital advertising, but it's across the piece. How do we present solutions to our clients, the marketers who are trying reach our audience, and our audience is valuable when they're growing. But also, there's technical innovation that we can bring to bear as well. So I think it's hard to pick sort of any one milestone. I think a really important milestone was what I mentioned in my opening comments, which was if you take the ad-free premium royalties that we get when people buy out their ads and they buy the Hulu premium stuff, and our nonlinear advertising inventory monetization, we actually overtook the decline that's coming from time shifted viewing away from the live window. And that's in the broadcast entertainment business. I think that is a big milestone, and it's one that we talked about a number of quarters ago and it's important. So those are the sorts of things that we're really focused on. 
And with respect to the Sky approval, as I said, we're confident we're going to get the deal done in the first half of next year. We're engaged with the regulators. This is a transaction that has cleared every relevant regulator in all the markets we operate in and has been through a thorough Phase 1 in the U.K. with Ofcom, which has looked at all these issues. And we're pretty confident it gets done. 
In general, in terms of capital allocation, I think, hopefully, we've shown you over the last number of years that we're very, very focused on being good stewards of capital, we're very, very focused on deploying capital where we can get great returns for all our shareholders, and that's what we're going to continue to do.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Maybe the first question, I think there's been some suggestion that you're looking to take some of your high-value content, particularly that from FX, off of platforms like Netflix. I was wondering if you could discuss how you think about distributing and
componenttext: Maybe the first question, I think there's been some suggestion that you're looking to take some of your high-value content, particularly that from FX, off of platforms like Netflix. I was wondering if you could discuss how you think about distributing and monetizing that content over the long term. Is it best kept on a platform that you own, or a platform that you partially own or third-party platforms? And then I think also, you've got your UFC rights coming up due next year, Thursday Night Football might also be in play, so maybe with both of those, if you could give us some color as to how you're thinking about shaping the sports rights portfolio.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Look, I'll start with the video-on-demand rights and Netflix. Look, our view is always to put the consumer first. We believe our rights should be on as many platforms as possible, ideally, on a nonexclusive basis, to put the consumer first. And that inclu
componenttext: Look, I'll start with the video-on-demand rights and Netflix. Look, our view is always to put the consumer first. We believe our rights should be on as many platforms as possible, ideally, on a nonexclusive basis, to put the consumer first. And that includes on platforms and apps that are branded with the home network that kind of was originally placed on. So it doesn't make any sense for the consumer not to be able to reach FX content through an FX-branded app. And this is the core part of our strategy. So you'll see us selling more of our content non-exclusively and across as many platforms as possible.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think that's 100% right. It's all about making our product more available, not less. And I think key to this as well is understanding that the licensing terms under which we're going to license this one, where these rights can have overall long
componenttext: Yes, and I think that's 100% right. It's all about making our product more available, not less. And I think key to this as well is understanding that the licensing terms under which we're going to license this one, where these rights can have overall long-term rights that we can monetize over time, that sometimes these big global exclusive SVOD licenses that Netflix, for example, favor, they don't fit for some strategies. So we've said that in the past, and that's going to continue. We're actually -- actually, our licensing on the Netflix side, for example, has actually declined a bit but it's been more of an -- it's been offset by other licenses that we've been able to put in place. So we feel pretty good about that, and I think our product performs particularly well in the streaming marketplace as well, when I look at everything from our animation business with -- from Futurama to Family Guy...

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Bob's Burgers.
componenttext: Bob's Burgers.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: To Bob's Burgers, to our scripted dramas and comedies from FX and FBC, we still -- we feel really good about its performance in the streaming marketplace. So that's where that is. Look, I don't want to get into any particular sports rights contract or neg
componenttext: To Bob's Burgers, to our scripted dramas and comedies from FX and FBC, we still -- we feel really good about its performance in the streaming marketplace. So that's where that is. Look, I don't want to get into any particular sports rights contract or negotiations that may be upcoming, but just philosophically, we look at this -- we have to look at it and around, and we think that sports continue to be a key driver of consumption, a key differentiator for a lot of our brands, but we always have to balance costs and benefit as you do. And we'll look at all of those things as they come up and try to make a decision around what's the right thing for our bottom line and for our customers. So sometimes, we choose to walk away from things, and sometimes, we choose to renew things. But we look at each and every one on the kind of merits and around those rights. So...

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: James, you have been very optimistic on the prospects of STAR TV and Hotstar going sort of global. Given the new IPL contract, which is $0.5 billion more, I think, in cost a year or for the next 5 years, can you talk about how that product is evolving and
componenttext: James, you have been very optimistic on the prospects of STAR TV and Hotstar going sort of global. Given the new IPL contract, which is $0.5 billion more, I think, in cost a year or for the next 5 years, can you talk about how that product is evolving and the confidence of the profitability measures you talked about for not only 2018, but 2020 that -- for $1 billion? And then just a clarification, obviously, you talked about your subscriber base being pretty stable and the virtual MVPDs growing. In those subscriber counts, are you counting the virtual MVPDs on your minimums or what's sort of been reported 2 months in areas?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's -- thanks, Vijay. Just on the STAR business, look, we are confident about it. We think we have a great team there, we have got a great business, and the marketplace is one of extraordinary opportunity in terms of its scale, in terms of the vibrancy o
componenttext:
It's -- thanks, Vijay. Just on the STAR business, look, we are confident about it. We think we have a great team there, we have got a great business, and the marketplace is one of extraordinary opportunity in terms of its scale, in terms of the vibrancy of the creative community, the vibrancy of the storytelling and sports there, et cetera. So we feel -- we do feel really good about it. As I mentioned earlier, we're on track for our short-term targets of $500 million of EBITDA this fiscal year. And I think we're -- and we're on track for the longer-term target, as you mentioned, of $1 billion of EBITDA in 2020. So I think that all feels good, even with the additional cost of the IPL. As John mentioned, in this fiscal year, it's the last quarter, we expect that increase in costs to be offset by an increase in revenue. And we think that the IPL is one of the great sports franchises in the world, and we think it's going to be able to deliver for the business. So it doesn't change that trajectory, but I think it makes it, over the course of the 5 years, quite a bit -- maybe a bit stronger. So we're -- we feel pretty good about it. 
With respect to Hotstar in general, look, I guess, as I think I've mentioned to all of you folks before, the real exciting opportunity here is an environment where you have just this incredible proliferation of video distribution on connected devices everywhere, where you have this -- and video consumption really driving so much of that consumption of connectivity generally. The opportunity in an environment where content really is king is to use that to build platforms. And we really see Hotstar as a platform in that way. So we're going to continue to iterate that product. But we think there's a lot to be done with it, both from a monetization point of view as well as an engagement point of view with customers, and you'll see new features. I hope -- I'd encourage everyone, the product is launched in the U.S. I'd encourage everybody to use it and use it. There's a lot of interesting features, a lot of social features, particularly around the way people watch sports together. So we feel great about it, but it's going to continue to change and the Hotstar platform will evolve rapidly.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: And Vijay, it's John. The -- your question on the VMVPDs. We are paid and counting billed subscribers, so it's not minimum, it's what customers are on those platforms. And as James and Lachlan referred to, the growth in this market has been not only great
componenttext: And Vijay, it's John. The -- your question on the VMVPDs. We are paid and counting billed subscribers, so it's not minimum, it's what customers are on those platforms. And as James and Lachlan referred to, the growth in this market has been not only great for the market, but for us because, again, we come back to the point that we are on every one of these. So it -- the offsets would come in, on cable, and we've heard from other companies, we see the inclusion on the VMVPDs as covering those.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017

componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the 21st Century Fox First Quarter 2018 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I'd now like to turn the conference over to our host, Mr. Reed Nolte, Executive Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our first quarter fiscal 2018 earnings conference call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, Executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial
componenttext:
Thank you very much, operator. Hello, everyone, and welcome to our first quarter fiscal 2018 earnings conference call. On the call today are Lachlan Murdoch, Executive Chairman; James Murdoch, Chief Executive Officer; and John Nallen, our Chief Financial Officer. 
First, we will give some prepared remarks on the most recent quarter, and we'll be happy to take questions from the investment community. This call may include certain forward-looking information with respect to 21st Century Fox' business strategy. Actual results could differ materially from what is said. 
The company's Form 10-Q for the 3 months ended September 30, 2017, identifies risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ, and these statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in such filings. 
Additionally, this call will include certain non-GAAP financial measurements. The definition of and a reconciliation of such measures can be found in our earnings release and our 10-Q filing. 
Please note that certain financial measures used in this call, such as segment operating income before depreciation and amortization, often referred to as EBITDA, and adjusted earnings per share are expressed on a non-GAAP basis. The GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures is included in our earnings release. 
And lastly, please note that our offer for Sky plc that was announced last December is covered by the U.K. takeover code. As such, there are strict limitations as to what we can say with respect to that transaction, and we are restricted to providing information that has been publicly announced. 
And with that, I'm pleased to turn the call over to Lachlan.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Reed, and good afternoon, everyone. Let me be very clear upfront that we have a long-standing policy of not commentating -- commenting on speculation around corporate activity or transactions. We will continue to adhere to that policy, meaning t
componenttext:
Thanks, Reed, and good afternoon, everyone. Let me be very clear upfront that we have a long-standing policy of not commentating -- commenting on speculation around corporate activity or transactions. 
We will continue to adhere to that policy, meaning that we will not be responding at all to questions or comments regarding recent press speculation. 
The purpose of this call is to focus on the growing and robust business of 21st Century Fox. We are pleased to report a solid start to fiscal 2018, which continues the operational and financial progress we delivered in fiscal '17. 
In the last quarter, we delivered 8% top line growth, with increases across all our reporting segments and revenue categories. We drove an acceleration in domestic affiliate revenue, which grew by 11%, sequentially surpassing the strong 10% growth in the prior quarter. 
We maintained our aggregate domestic subscriber levels, offsetting declines in the traditional pay TV universe, with growing contribution from our younger channel and our new digital MVPD partners. 
The latter now approaches 3 million subscribers despite only limited marketing for their products so far. 
We talk often about our unique competitive advantage of our strength in local and national sports and news in an environment with increased viewing optionality, and this trend continues. 
We essentially doubled college football viewership from higher ratings and more games. We grew our Major League Baseball regular season ratings at our RSNs by 5%, with 7 teams up double digits, and more recently finished October as the most watched month in FOX Sports 1 history on the back of postseason baseball. 
And speaking of baseball, it was another great 7-game World Series for us, both onscreen and financially. 
Fox News maintains its position as the #1 network on basic cable and had its 63rd consecutive quarter as the highest-rated cable news channel in total viewers. 
And while the local stations face a difficult comparison with the heavy political advertising last year, the underlying market is up, led by a healthy auto category and improving retail advertising. 
In entertainment, our Film and Television divisions continue to create new hits to refresh longer-term content revenue streams.
At FBC, The Gifted, The Orville and Ghosted have all performed well as freshmen series. At FX, 3 returning shows, The Strain, Better Things and American Horror Story, all increased their viewership over the prior year quarter. 
And National Geographic continues its focus on brand-supportive content, including the upcoming Long Road Home series. 
And at our film studio, we have a strong upcoming slate that includes Murder on the Orient Express this weekend, The Greatest Showman, The Post by Steven Spielberg, X-Men: New Mutants and Deadpool 2. 
Overall, our performance underscores the success of our core strategies, including owning and investing in distinctive must-have brands and IP, distributed to global consumers every minute of every day. 
The power of these strong and unique brands supports our content, our advertising and critically, our leading growth in affiliate fee revenues; continually expanding our deep and unique access to international markets through an unparalleled global footprint, with particular emphasis in one of the largest growth economies in the world, India; and challenging the status quo by consistently driving innovation across our businesses by leaning into new distribution models, new ad tech monetization capabilities and being a global leader in direct-to-consumer offerings. 
For example, we told you many years ago that innovative disruption would come to our industry. We embraced it and continued to see more and more exciting changes and resulting opportunities. 
We moved early to jettison our thin brands and went deep with investments into our rich, distinctive brands when many market pundits were skeptical of this approach. Because of these investments, our brands have been rewarded with full distribution on all traditional and newly launched platforms. 
Now there is a lot of talk about the growing importance of scale in the media industry, and let me be very clear, FOX has the required scale to continue to both execute on our growth strategy and deliver increased returns to shareholders. 
We are specifically seeing this in our affiliate fee growth again this quarter, in the success of Hulu and in our inclusion in all of the emerging VMVPDs. 
We are excited about all of our brands and the breadth of opportunities they continue to offer the company. All in all, our progress in the quarter keeps us on pace with our fiscal 2018 objectives and directly in line with our long-term plan, however, long-term delivery coming from an intense day-to-day focus towards being the very best in storytelling, in journalism, in sports and in innovation to consumers worldwide. 
Driving these businesses is a stellar management team, from Peter Rice at the Fox Networks Groups, to Uday Shankar's STAR, Stacey Snider, John Landgraf, Eric Shanks, Carlos Martinez, Dana Walden, Gary Newman, Jack Abernethy, Brian Sullivan, along with our 22,000 colleagues around the world, we are singularly and intensely focused on delivering on our strategic plan. 
Our businesses and brands are stronger than ever and have the right management and strategies to achieve market-leading value accretion. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to John.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lachlan, and good afternoon, everyone. We reported our first quarter financial results today, highlighted by revenue growing 8% to reach $7 billion. It was led by double-digit growth at the Cable Network segment and increases at the Film and Telev
componenttext:
Thanks, Lachlan, and good afternoon, everyone. We reported our first quarter financial results today, highlighted by revenue growing 8% to reach $7 billion. It was led by double-digit growth at the Cable Network segment and increases at the Film and Television segments. 
Segment EBITDA for the quarter of $1.79 billion was in line with last year's result as company-wide revenue growth was offset by expected higher cost, largely due to the higher volume of sports events broadcasts in the current quarter at the Cable and Television segments. 
From a bottom line perspective, we reported income from continuing operations attributable to stockholders of $839 million or $0.45 per share, while adjusted EPS was $0.49. 
So with those highlights, I'll provide some added comments on the performance of our operating segments for the quarter and starting with the Cable Network segment, where EBITDA of $1.51 billion was up 9% on revenue growth of 10% and expense growth, primarily from sports volume, of 11%. But notably, this expense increase reflects a 2-percentage point impact from the inclusion of sublicense sports rights. 
Domestic cable revenues increased 9%, led by 11% affiliate fee growth and advertising revenue growth of 3%. The affiliate fee increase reflects higher average rates across all of our domestic brands. The advertising growth largely reflects higher viewership across our sports network. 
EBITDA at our domestic channels increased 11% over the prior year, reflecting these higher revenues, partially offset by increased costs from added college football and soccer games at FS1 and Major League Baseball rights increases at FS1 and the RSNs. 
Reported international cable revenues grew 13%, driven also by an 11% increase in reported affiliate revenue and a 10% increase in reported advertising revenue. 
International content and other revenues increased 35% over the prior year due to the sublicensing of Latin American soccer rights to third parties, which is offset in expenses. 
Reported international EBITDA contributions were consistent with the prior year, reflecting the higher revenues being offset by expected higher programming costs, largely from increased soccer in Latin America from the inaugural broadcast of the Argentine Football Association and from the timing of Conmebol matches. 
At our Television segment, EBITDA was $122 million, 36% below last year. Television segment revenues grew 3% on higher retransmission consent revenue and increased sports advertising revenue from a higher volume of college football games and one additional NFL game. These ad sale gains were partially offset by reduced political advertising at the stations. 
Our net revenue improvement was more than offset by higher sports rights from the increased volume of football games and normal rights increases. 
At the Film segment, first quarter EBITDA of $256 million was $55 million below a year ago. This decrease was primarily driven by lower contributions at the Film division, led by lower sales in international TV markets. 
Overall, Film segment revenues in the quarter were 3% higher than the prior year, primarily due to higher Television production revenues led by the domestic syndication sale of Futurama. 
And finally, from a balance sheet perspective, we ended the quarter with $6.9 billion in cash and $19.8 billion in debt. Our capital allocation priority continues to be focused on funding the Sky acquisition. 
So all in all, a good start to achieving our fiscal 2018 financial objectives. On our last earnings call, I mentioned a number of comparability items to be aware of as we progressed through this fiscal year, and at this time, I don't have any meaningful changes to those items. 
So one addition of note since the call is our successful acquisition of the IPL cricket rights in India starting this coming spring. These worldwide rights will add approximately 3 percentage points of cost growth to the Cable segment, and we expect a similar dollar amount of incremental revenues to be generated from these matches all in the fourth quarter. 
And with that, let me turn it over to James.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, John and Lachlan. Thanks, everyone, for joining the call today. So as you've heard, fiscal 2018 has started pretty well. One quarter in, we're on track to generate meaningful growth and to deliver operational advances that are going to
componenttext:
Thanks very much, John and Lachlan. Thanks, everyone, for joining the call today. 
So as you've heard, fiscal 2018 has started pretty well. One quarter in, we're on track to generate meaningful growth and to deliver operational advances that are going to serve the company well going forward. 
We're committed to our strategy of producing both highly localized content around the world and broad global franchises that travel well and together, build resident brands in our marketplace -- in our key markets. 
New digital platforms, in partnership with us, are leading the way and improving the customer experience and allowing us to make high-quality storytelling, sports and news programming more available, not less, which will drive further consumption of our content and more visibility into that consumption by our customers, strengthening our business. 
And across the company, the whole company, we're making really good progress. For example, in Argentina, which will soon be our largest South American market, the launch of our premium sports business, anchored by our long-term rights agreement with the AFA, has exceeded all of our expectations. 
We've added more local stations in sports to FOX NOW. The international rollouts of Fox Plus and FOX Premium continue to gain traction. And Hotstar, which continues to set the pace for streaming in India, recently launched internationally for the Indian diaspora, providing opportunities to further monetize our Indian investments. 
Additionally, the rollout of FX+ on Comcast systems, which allows us to resurface, repackage and monetize great content from our library as well as current output in an ad-free premium environment, is showing great promise. 
It also recently launched on Cox systems, and others are expected to follow shortly. 
Our commitment to deliver a less cluttered viewing experience does not necessarily come at the expense of lower advertising yields. 6-second spots during the NFL, the launch of Open AP, addressable ads in on-demand and streaming on Hulu are all examples of innovation we have embraced in this space. In fact, Fox Networks Group digital ad revenue in aggregate is up 30% year-over-year, with revenue per stream on our apps up 50% at FBC, 130% at FX and up 300% at FOX Sports. 
Perhaps most encouragingly, as we predicted to you over a year ago at our broadcast network entertainment business, the combination of ad-free premiums and nonlinear advertising sales now outpaces the linear revenue decline driven by customers' preference for time-shifting their viewing. 
Before closing, I'd like to reiterate 2 meaningful milestones we expect to achieve before the end of this fiscal year. First, at STAR, our significant past investments and current investments in entertainment, sports, regional and our mobile platform, Hotstar, position the company as the premier Indian content and digital distribution company. 
First quarter results keep us on plan to achieve $500 million of EBITDA target this fiscal year as projected and with velocity heading into the next few years. 
And as John mentioned, STAR just recently took its final step in the realignment of its sports portfolio with the acquisition of those 5-year rights for the Indian Premier League, the most attended and watched cricket league in the world. Exclusive global rights across broadcasting and digital will be a key growth driver of this business going forward. 
These rights cement our confidence in achieving our financial targets for our Indian business, and our aspiration for the business over the long-term continues to grow. 
Secondly, we're engaging with the U.K. regulators on our proposed Sky acquisition. We're confident this transaction will accelerate the company's operational and financial growth, and we anticipate the transaction to close by the middle of 2018. 
In conclusion, the trajectory and the velocity of the business are good. The business is well positioned, we've made a lot of progress, and we're excited about the upcoming years. 
And as Lachlan pointed out, we can't comment on market speculation, but we're happy to discuss our business and the quarter's results. So over to you.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: I will stick with one topic, which is the virtual MVPD trends you're seeing in the U.S. I don't know, John, if you're willing to give us a little more granularity on what drove what seemed to be a pretty nice acceleration in affiliate revenues in the U.S.
componenttext:
I will stick with one topic, which is the virtual MVPD trends you're seeing in the U.S. I don't know, John, if you're willing to give us a little more granularity on what drove what seemed to be a pretty nice acceleration in affiliate revenues in the U.S. I don't believe you had any renewals at the end of June. So I'm wondering if maybe the volumes got better overall for you. So any color there would be helpful. 
And then I wanted to ask the team about Hulu, which is obviously a major player in that 3 million subscriber number you mentioned. You made a management change -- or there was a management change made there recently. Maybe if you can just talk about how you're feeling about Hulu's live product, the sort of product road map, and whether you still are excited about what that business can do from a bundle perspective going forward.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben. It's John to start. Volumes held up pretty well for us. The inclusion or the advent of these VMVPD products have just been a real success in capturing subs, either from traditional or Hulu or outside the system altogether. So the real growth
componenttext: Thanks, Ben. It's John to start. Volumes held up pretty well for us. The inclusion or the advent of these VMVPD products have just been a real success in capturing subs, either from traditional or Hulu or outside the system altogether. So the real growth that we achieved on the 11% was in rate step-ups across every one of our brands. And it goes back to the point that both James and Lachlan were making, we spent a long time investing in these brands, and now we're harvesting the value from them.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, and Ben, I think that's right. So you have this -- we have this rate increase from previous -- step-ups from previous affiliate agreements, not in the quarter, but volume holding up well. And look, it's a little bit mixed. I think you saw the telco k
componenttext:
Yes, and Ben, I think that's right. So you have this -- we have this rate increase from previous -- step-ups from previous affiliate agreements, not in the quarter, but volume holding up well. And look, it's a little bit mixed. I think you saw the telco kind of distributors shrink at a greater rate than some of the cable and DBS. But fundamentally, new competition is driving growth, right? And I think in the -- from a billable subs perspective, this is on a couple of months' lag in these numbers of about 2 million, but just in the last few months, they have added another million of VMVPDs, right? So it's almost 3 million, as Lachlan mentioned today. And that's only going to accelerate from here because really, that's prior to the marketing that we saw from YouTube, the upcoming kind of more aggressive marketing from Hulu, and we think others as well. DIRECTV NOW, Sling, fubo, with its sports focus and a slightly different kind of package, is growing well. So we feel really good about that. And I think it's important, just before I get to Hulu, to reemphasize that the streaming MVPD, the VMVPD, if you will, is a really great platform for us. And we think it's an incredible set of platforms for monetizing our programming and our investment, and it's a great user experience as well. And it's really in line with what we've been trying to accomplish and have been talking to all of you guys about over the last couple of years, and I think you can really start to see that coming through in this quarter. 
With respect to Hulu, yes, look, I wouldn't read too much into the management change. I mean, Mike Hopkins left to take a great job at Sony, is a longtime colleague of ours and was a great leader of Hulu. And I'm really excited for Randy Freer, who came out of the Fox Networks Group to go over to Hulu very recently, and we're sure that that's going to continue -- that's going to help continue the momentum and really good pace that the Hulu business has. So we feel good about Hulu Live. It's growing well. It's early days. We feel great about Hulu's product and product road map. And I think what we're going to see is Hulu and a number of other of these VMVPDs continue to be real pacesetters in the marketplace, both from a customer experience perspective, a content offering perspective and a volume perspective, offsetting a lot of the declines that we've seen over the last sort of while. And as I think I've said in the last quarterly call, we expected actually -- we think that the so-called pay TV universe, the universe of people paying for video services, in these multiservice providers is actually going to grow.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017

componenttext: And look, James -- yes, and look, I think -- sorry, Ben. headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: I'm not going to ask about press speculation, but I'll ask about strategy. I think there's been a perception, right or wrong, that FOX and News Corp before has always been a collector of assets. And I wonder, can you share your view of whether or not the
componenttext: I'm not going to ask about press speculation, but I'll ask about strategy. I think there's been a perception, right or wrong, that FOX and News Corp before has always been a collector of assets. And I wonder, can you share your view of whether or not the industry's trends have changed enough that makes you rethink your asset mix for the long term? Aside from getting Sky, so I just want to know just thematically, if you got it at the right scale, does scale matter as much in entertainment as it maybe once did, or does it matter more?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael. It's James here. I'll just take a crack at it, and then Lachlan might want to jump in. But look, first of all, I don't think we're -- I -- yes, we're not a collector, we're an operator. And I think what we try to do is build a business th
componenttext: Thanks, Michael. It's James here. I'll just take a crack at it, and then Lachlan might want to jump in. But look, first of all, I don't think we're -- I -- yes, we're not a collector, we're an operator. And I think what we try to do is build a business that can have pace, that can have velocity, that can deliver value over the long term. And as you know, we've taken a lot of steps to change our portfolio over the last number of years, simplifying our mix of assets, investing in these core brands, selling assets that weren't going to change our lives in terms of a lot of the -- I can go all the way back to the Russian outdoor business, which we exited a number of years ago. So I think the point for us is we've really simplified our operating model. We've got a great set of brands and a great set of assets that we really like. And as you can see from these quarterly results and from the last couple of quarters, I hope, a real trajectory of good performance in those. It's never easy. We're focused on operating these businesses as best we can with a really incredible management team at all of these businesses, and we can continue to be focused on that. So we like that mix, we like these brands, and we're seeing them really perform around the world, from STAR to the FOX businesses around the world, National Geographic. These are big brands that really matter for their customers, and we like where we are.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Look, James, that's 100% correct. And look, I think, historically, the truth is we've always been asset-builders, and whether it's Sky or STAR or Fox News or the Fox Network, we operate these businesses to build them and to grow, and we will continue to d
componenttext: Look, James, that's 100% correct. And look, I think, historically, the truth is we've always been asset-builders, and whether it's Sky or STAR or Fox News or the Fox Network, we operate these businesses to build them and to grow, and we will continue to do so.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say to both of you guys, I think many people on The Street see the growth and the value you've created, and they're frustrated the stock has not reflected that growth and you trade at levels that are closer to some companies that don't grow.
componenttext: Well, I would say to both of you guys, I think many people on The Street see the growth and the value you've created, and they're frustrated the stock has not reflected that growth and you trade at levels that are closer to some companies that don't grow. So is there a frustration within the family or the executives that you're not getting credit for all of the things you've done over the many years?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Look, all we can do is work on what we can control, and that's operating these businesses and growing the businesses. And that's what every single member of senior management is focused on.
componenttext: Look, all we can do is work on what we can control, and that's operating these businesses and growing the businesses. And that's what every single member of senior management is focused on.

componenttext: I had a question on, I guess, 2 things, one, the -- on the ad tech platform. Can you -- you talked about kind of the stuff you're doing now. Can you talk about milestones for the year or 2 ahead? What will finally tip the scales for targeted advertising? And then, I guess, to think of the unthinkable, if you don't get the Sky approval, given all the kind of political stuff going on in the U.K., how do you think about the use of excess capital?

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jessica. In terms of a -- It's James. It terms of the advertising capability, we continue to improve our ad capability across the piece. I think there are a few milestones to look at. I think the adoption of standards across the sort of streaming
componenttext:
Thanks, Jessica. In terms of a -- It's James. It terms of the advertising capability, we continue to improve our ad capability across the piece. I think there are a few milestones to look at. I think the adoption of standards across the sort of streaming video industry, I think the Open AP platform, which we're a big proponent of, I think is important. I think seeing third-party verification really take root across digital advertising, both on -- from social networks to streaming video platforms, I think is going to be really important. And then there's an industry thing that we're working very hard to sort of get in place. But fundamentally, we're not waiting on that to innovate, right? So I look at it and think, let's not wait to try to move this whole kind of armada of companies to something, let's actually go out there and iterate and find the ad products that are going to make sense for customers. And that's an ad product that, for example, you could buy out if you're a customer and not have ads and you value your time more than Coca-Cola does, or it's ad products that are great for customers in pitching changes, like the 6-second spots and picture-in-picture stuff. So it's not just digital advertising, but it's across the piece. How do we present solutions to our clients, the marketers who are trying reach our audience, and our audience is valuable when they're growing. But also, there's technical innovation that we can bring to bear as well. So I think it's hard to pick sort of any one milestone. I think a really important milestone was what I mentioned in my opening comments, which was if you take the ad-free premium royalties that we get when people buy out their ads and they buy the Hulu premium stuff, and our nonlinear advertising inventory monetization, we actually overtook the decline that's coming from time shifted viewing away from the live window. And that's in the broadcast entertainment business. I think that is a big milestone, and it's one that we talked about a number of quarters ago and it's important. So those are the sorts of things that we're really focused on. 
And with respect to the Sky approval, as I said, we're confident we're going to get the deal done in the first half of next year. We're engaged with the regulators. This is a transaction that has cleared every relevant regulator in all the markets we operate in and has been through a thorough Phase 1 in the U.K. with Ofcom, which has looked at all these issues. And we're pretty confident it gets done. 
In general, in terms of capital allocation, I think, hopefully, we've shown you over the last number of years that we're very, very focused on being good stewards of capital, we're very, very focused on deploying capital where we can get great returns for all our shareholders, and that's what we're going to continue to do.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Maybe the first question, I think there's been some suggestion that you're looking to take some of your high-value content, particularly that from FX, off of platforms like Netflix. I was wondering if you could discuss how you think about distributing and
componenttext: Maybe the first question, I think there's been some suggestion that you're looking to take some of your high-value content, particularly that from FX, off of platforms like Netflix. I was wondering if you could discuss how you think about distributing and monetizing that content over the long term. Is it best kept on a platform that you own, or a platform that you partially own or third-party platforms? And then I think also, you've got your UFC rights coming up due next year, Thursday Night Football might also be in play, so maybe with both of those, if you could give us some color as to how you're thinking about shaping the sports rights portfolio.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Look, I'll start with the video-on-demand rights and Netflix. Look, our view is always to put the consumer first. We believe our rights should be on as many platforms as possible, ideally, on a nonexclusive basis, to put the consumer first. And that inclu
componenttext: Look, I'll start with the video-on-demand rights and Netflix. Look, our view is always to put the consumer first. We believe our rights should be on as many platforms as possible, ideally, on a nonexclusive basis, to put the consumer first. And that includes on platforms and apps that are branded with the home network that kind of was originally placed on. So it doesn't make any sense for the consumer not to be able to reach FX content through an FX-branded app. And this is the core part of our strategy. So you'll see us selling more of our content non-exclusively and across as many platforms as possible.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think that's 100% right. It's all about making our product more available, not less. And I think key to this as well is understanding that the licensing terms under which we're going to license this one, where these rights can have overall long
componenttext: Yes, and I think that's 100% right. It's all about making our product more available, not less. And I think key to this as well is understanding that the licensing terms under which we're going to license this one, where these rights can have overall long-term rights that we can monetize over time, that sometimes these big global exclusive SVOD licenses that Netflix, for example, favor, they don't fit for some strategies. So we've said that in the past, and that's going to continue. We're actually -- actually, our licensing on the Netflix side, for example, has actually declined a bit but it's been more of an -- it's been offset by other licenses that we've been able to put in place. So we feel pretty good about that, and I think our product performs particularly well in the streaming marketplace as well, when I look at everything from our animation business with -- from Futurama to Family Guy...

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017

componenttext: Bob's Burgers.

headline: Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc., Q1 2018 Earnings Call, Nov 09, 2017
componenttextpreview: To Bob's Burgers, to our scripted dramas and comedies from FX and FBC, we still -- we feel really good about its performance in the streaming marketplace. So that's where that is. Look, I don't want to get into any particular sports rights contract or neg
componenttext: To Bob's Burgers, to our scripted dramas and comedies from FX and FBC, we still -- we feel really good about its performance in the streaming marketplace. So that's where that is. Look, I don't want to get into any particular sports rights contract or negotiations that may be upcoming, but just philosophically, we look at this -- we have to look at it and around, and we think that sports continue to be a key driver of consumption, a key differentiator for a lot of our brands, but we always have to balance costs and benefit as you do. And we'll look at all of those things as they come up and try to make a decision around what's the right thing for our bottom line and for our customers. So sometimes, we choose to walk away from things, and sometimes, we choose to renew things. But we look at each and every one on the kind of merits and around those rights. So...
